title: Analysis and prediction of bug duplicates in KDE bug tracking system

author: Gregor Leban, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute

So backtracking systems are tools that we can use.
The users can users of a particular product can use in order to report some issues that they detected with the software back to the developers.

In launchpad.

People can ask for additional information about the bugs, or they can provide some additional information how to replicate the bug and so on.
Along with the description in these comments, we also have some meta information for each bug, in this case, Bugzilla allows us to specify the product of where this bug belongs to some component.
So component is part of the product and also some additional information like is the bug new or so on.
The targets, the version with this bug appears and so on.
So mainly what's important in this meta information is the date of the bug.
So when the bug was reported 1st and also the product and component.
So back tracking systems are very useful, but they have a problem and the problem is that when users report bug issues, they typically don't check if the same issue was already reported in the past.

So what people typically happens is that people create some new bug report that describes the same bug that was already reported in the past, and when that happens we say that they have created a bug duplicate.
